cases.raw_reasoning: Section 11 of the Probation of Offenders Act explicitly empowers appellate and revisional courts, including the High Court, to make orders under the Act notwithstanding prior conviction, allowing application post the Act's enforcement in the district before appeal disposal. The appellant, aged 16 and guilty of non-capital offences, falls squarely under the mandatory reformative provisions of s.6, prioritizing probation over imprisonment absent recorded reasons otherwise. The Act's beneficial, non-retrospective bar is overcome by s.11's expansive jurisdiction, outweighing procedural delay arguments given the penological reform objective.

cases.graph_reasoning: Precedents such as Buckingham Carnatic and others strictly limit Tribunal interference with domestic enquiries and punishment to cases of proven victimization, lack of bona fides, unfair labour practice, or natural justice violations, which the petitioner argues are absent from the record. Even assuming a strike (not illegal), the Tribunal overstepped by substituting its view on punishment quantum without showing shockingly disproportionate under Wednesbury unreasonableness, as dismissal for collective one-day unauthorized absence amid work pressure is within reasonable employer discretion. The procedural flaw in the reference (11 vs 8 workmen) further weakens the Tribunal's order.
cases.raw_reasoning: The tribunal found the one-day absence constituted a non-illegal strike due to a bona fide dispute over holiday practice, and dismissal was disproportionate victimization, especially as the domestic enquiry only recommended dismissal for 8 out of 11 workmen. Supreme Court in industrial disputes often defers to tribunal findings unless perverse, and here the punishment appears harsh for a single day's concerted absence amid unclear communication on holiday status. The Court's preliminary remark on not interfering with the award for technical reasons regarding three workmen further indicates reluctance to overturn the reinstatement order.

cases.graph_reasoning: The assessments on the HUF were finalized between 1948 and 1950 without a contemporaneous order under Section 25A(1), rendering them conclusive. A subsequent 1952 order under Section 25A(1) cannot retrospectively reopen these final assessments or trigger the proviso to Section 25A(2) to impose joint and several personal liability on the members. Consequently, recovery of HUF tax arrears from the members' personal salaries as company employees is invalid, favoring the petitioners' appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The statutory scheme under Section 25A of the 1922 Act requires, after recording partition under sub-section (1), an apportionment order under sub-section (2) to fix individual liability on members before recovery can be effected against them personally, as per the proviso to sub-section (2). Here, assessments were made on the HUF, partition recorded in 1952 under 25A(1), but no 25A(2) order preceded the 1958 garnishee notice under Section 46(5), rendering recovery from petitioners' salaries invalid. The Supreme Court would likely uphold the High Court's strict interpretation mandating procedural compliance for enforcing HUF tax dues post-disruption.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's arguments on mandatory concurrency under CrPC s.397, single charge under s.222, and joint trials under ss.234/235 fail as these are discretionary/enabling provisions, not obligatory, and separate trials/charges for distinct offences over different amounts/dates were legally permissible without prejudice. The total 11-year sentence under s.409 IPC for a public servant's repeated criminal breach of trust involving public funds is not excessive, aligning with the need for deterrence, and the High Court deemed even 4 years lenient. Supreme Court under Art.136 rarely interferes in sentencing absent perversity or illegality, which is absent here.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's argument under s.222(2) CrPC for treating multiple misappropriations as a single offence was not raised before the Sessions Court or High Court, limiting its viability at the Supreme Court stage on sentence alone. The High Court deemed the sentences lenient for serious s.409 IPC offences by a public servant, and consecutive sentencing under s.397 CrPC is standard absent a direction for concurrency, which was not improperly denied. No illegality or perversity in sentencing warrants Supreme Court interference.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts demonstrate a coordinated group assault with prior concert, involving chasing, holding down, and beating with weapons, supporting application of Section 34 IPC to the criminal act of culpable homicide under Section 304 Part II. The Full Bench precedent in Ibra Akanda v. Emperor explicitly allows reading Section 34 with Section 304 Part II, outweighing the minority view and cases cited by petitioners like Ramnath v. Emperor. The Supreme Court is likely to uphold the conviction given the sufficiency of evidence for common intention and shared knowledge of likely death.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Court assumes the prosecution facts, infers a clear prior concert and common intention among the appellants from their coordinated actions in chasing, holding down, and assaulting the victim with weapons. It favors the majority and Full Bench views (e.g., Saidu Khan v. State) permitting s.34 IPC to be read with s.304 Part II over the appellants' cited minority opinions. This strongly supports upholding the conviction under s.304 Part II r/w s.34, leading to rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court has previously upheld s.34(1A)'s validity in Jai Kishan Srivastava, applying the reasonable classification test under Art.14 due to the distinct class of large escaped incomes (>=Rs.1 lakh) during the 1939-1946 war period with nexus to hidden profits. Notices under s.34(1A) are deemed equivalent to those under s.34(1) via s.22(2), preserving appeals and revisions, while the lack of limitation is rationally justified. Petitioner arguments on discrimination fail against this established framework and procedural compliance issues lack merit from presented facts.
cases.raw_reasoning: Section 34(1A) creates a reasonable classification based on the specific historical period (1939-1946) linked to widespread tax evasion during wartime, justifying differential treatment like no limitation period and denial of appeals to expedite recovery of large escaped incomes. Assessees under this section are not similarly situated to those under Section 34(1), as the provision targets a distinct class with a rational nexus to the legislative object of addressing past non-disclosures. The Supreme Court is likely to uphold the section against Article 14 challenge, rejecting the appeals as the High Court did.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's reliance on Kameshwar Prasad and O.K. Ghosh is misplaced, as those cases invalidated conduct rules prohibiting mere demonstrations under Art.19(1)(a) and (b), whereas here the charge is under the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance prohibiting strikes in essential services, for which there is no fundamental right as per All India Bank Employees Association. The Ordinance is constitutionally valid, with no restriction on speech or assembly beyond reasonable limits, and undisputed facts (union secretary arrested in demonstration just before illegal strike) provide sufficient evidence for the disciplinary authority's finding. Thus, the punishment does not violate fundamental rights, and the petition is likely to be dismissed.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance validly prohibits strikes in postal/telegraph services under public interest, with no fundamental right to strike as affirmed in prior cases like the Bank Employees case. Petitioner's reliance on Kameshwar Prasad and O. Ghosh is inapplicable, as those invalidated conduct rules under Art.19(1)(c), not specific essential services legislation. Sufficient evidence from arrest during demonstration supports the departmental inquiry's finding of guilt, warranting rejection of the writ petition.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal principles under Section 13 and its proviso, along with established doctrines on stock-in-trade valuation, mandate including closing stock value (cost or market price, whichever lower) to ascertain true profits, even under cash system of accounting. Precedents like Cock Russell and Whimster emphasize commercial accounting requiring stock adjustments, rendering the assessee's method inadequate for proper profit deduction. The dissolution deed value is extra-commercial and not binding, justifying the Tribunal's application of the proviso and confirmation of assessment with stock inclusion.
cases.raw_reasoning: The assessee's accounting method debited the full cost of film exploitation rights but ignored the value of unexpired rights at year-end, understating true profits. Under Section 10 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, the Income-tax Officer is not bound by a method that does not reflect actual profits, and valuation of closing stock (like film rights as stock-in-trade) is mandatory on a mercantile basis. The dissolution agreement's low valuation was rightly rejected as extra-commercial, supporting the authorities' estimation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's plea under Order 2 Rule 2 CPC fails procedurally because the pleadings of the previous suit were not filed in evidence, which is mandatory to prove the identity of the cause of action, as emphasized in the legal concepts analogous to res judicata. Lower courts correctly rejected the plea on this ground, and the appellant's arguments relying on inference or consent lack evidentiary support under Order 41 Rule 27. Even on merits, suits for possession and mesne profits may not share the same cause of action per Order 2 Rule 4, but the procedural defect alone dooms the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's plea under Order 2 Rule 2 CPC fails primarily because the pleadings of the prior suit (CS 28/1950) were not placed on record, depriving the court of material to assess omitted reliefs. Both the District Judge and High Court correctly noted this evidentiary gap, remanding for trial on merits. The Supreme Court, agreeing no material exists for the bar, would reject the appeal without resolving the conflict on whether possession and mesne profits share the same cause of action.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Madhya Pradesh Legislature exercised independent legislative power under Entry 24, List III, to enact Act No. 16 of 1962, fixing minimum wages afresh with retrospective effect from 1959 but payable from 1962, distinguishing it from mere validation of the struck-down 1958 notification. Retrospective operation does not violate Article 19(1)(f) or (g), as supported by Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar, since it is not unreasonable for curing defects post-judgment. No Article 20(1) violation occurs, as liability for wages and prosecution arises only from 21 June 1962, making the restrictions prospective in enforcement.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Madhya Pradesh Legislature validly exercised its power under the concurrent legislative field to fix minimum wages directly by statute, bypassing the procedural requirements of the Central Minimum Wages Act, 1948, as these apply to executive notifications rather than legislative enactments. Retrospective effect from 1959 does not violate Article 19(1)(f)/(g) as it constitutes a reasonable restriction in the interest of workers' welfare, and Article 20(1) is inapplicable since it pertains to criminal ex post facto laws, not civil wage liabilities. Prior judicial invalidation of executive notifications does not preclude curative legislation deeming the rates valid ab initio.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Sales Tax Officer has clear jurisdiction under Section 7(4) to amend for errors, but the integral relation/commercially inexpedient test under Section 8(3)(b) and Rule 13 likely supports retaining drawing instruments, photographic materials, and electricals as integral to design and normal manufacturing operations. Building materials like cement and lime (beyond tiles) and coal may not qualify if primarily for construction rather than processing, indicating partial acceptance of the appeal. The cited precedent in Indian Copper Corporation broadly interprets Rule 13 to include indirect necessities like vehicles, favoring the petitioner's position on covered items.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court excerpt criticizes the High Court for exceeding the scope of the writ petition by ruling on items like colours, chemicals, and machinery that the Sales Tax Officer did not order to be deleted, which was not open to the High Court. This procedural irregularity, combined with the affirmation of the STO's jurisdiction under Section 7(4), indicates the appeal will likely be accepted, setting aside or modifying the High Court's order. On merits, disputed items like drawing instruments and photographic materials may not qualify under Section 8(3)(b), but the High Court's overreach provides grounds for reversal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The scheme under U.P. Act s.3 satisfies s.68C MV Act requirements as they are substantially identical, with defects cured post-remand via objections. The '16 or more or less' clause offers flexibility for adequate service. Precedents confirm schemes can curtail area-based permits by excluding routes/portions, aligning with ss.51(2) and 68F, rejecting petitioner's distinctions.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's primary contention that the scheme, originally framed under Section 3 of the U.P. Road Transport Services Development Act, 1955, was merely approved without change under Section 68C of the Motor Vehicles Act lacks merit, as the record shows it was reconsidered, notified afresh under Chapter IVA post-amendment, published in 1959, and objections properly considered after remand in compliance with Section 68D. The minor modification in 1963 to specify the number of services further aligns with Section 68C's requirements for detailing the nature of services. Given the High Court's consistent rejection and the procedural adherence, the Supreme Court is likely to dismiss the appeal upholding the nationalization scheme.

cases.graph_reasoning: The termination was a simple discharge under the contractual terms of one month's notice, not a punishment under Rule 6(3)(v), rendering the employee's appeal incompetent under Rule 6(6) and the State Government's order without jurisdiction. Rule 6 requiring Labour Commissioner's concurrence falls within the rule-making power under Section 49(2) of the Factories Act. The State, even if acting quasi-judicially, lacked authority to entertain the appeal, warranting the Supreme Court setting aside its order under Article 136.
cases.raw_reasoning: The State of Punjab exercising appellate power under Rule 6(6) acts quasi-judicially by adjudicating the dispute over termination after considering the employee's appeal and the employer's written statement, qualifying it as a 'tribunal' under Article 136, rendering the appeal maintainable. On merits, the Welfare Officer accepted all-India transfer liability per his appointment letter, and his refusal to join the Kymore Works despite protracted correspondence constituted abandonment of service, validating the termination without need for further formal notice. The State's reinstatement order is thus erroneous, warranting it being set aside.

cases.graph_reasoning: The challenge to section 1(3) of the ESI Act under Article 14 and excessive delegation lacks merit, as precedents like Queen v. Burah establish it as valid conditional legislation guided by the Act's welfare scheme, not unguided delegation. The petitioners' grievance over inferior standardized medical benefits does not violate equality, as the Act aims for uniform social security, and superior prior benefits do not create a vested right against statutory coverage. Writ jurisdiction under Article 226 is inappropriate due to alternative remedies under the Industrial Disputes Act and ESI Act.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants' challenge to section 1(3) of the ESI Act on grounds of excessive delegation is weak, as the provision constitutes conditional legislation with clear guidance from the Act's preamble and scheme aimed at providing uniform social security benefits, consistent with precedents like Queen v. Burah. No apparent violation of Article 14 is evident, given the uniform application across areas without arbitrary discrimination. The workmen'S grievance over inferior benefits does not invalidate the statute's rollout mechanism.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant corporation is a separate legal entity under the Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950, distinct from the State, so its income does not qualify as 'income of a State' exempt under Article 289(1). Road transport is a commercial trade or business activity, falling under the exception in Article 289(2) without a declaration under clause (3), and precedents like State of West Bengal v. Union of India reject broad immunity doctrines. It qualifies as a 'company' assessee under Section 3 of the Income Tax Act, negating claims of non-assessability or local authority status.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation is a distinct statutory body corporate under the Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950, not the 'State' itself, so its income does not qualify for exemption under Article 289(1). The High Court correctly held it is not carrying on business on behalf of the Government, and the appellant concedes the activity is not incidental to ordinary government functions, making it taxable under Article 289(2). Arguments on assessee categories and local authority status lack merit as the entity fits within taxable frameworks.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 119A of the RPA 1951 does not prescribe any penalty for non-compliance with the deposit requirement, explicitly preserving the court's jurisdiction and discretion to permit rectification of defects. The deposit was tendered in good faith to the High Court Registrar, accepted without objection, and numbered, aligning with the doctrine of actus curiae neminem gravabit to prevent prejudice to litigants. Precedent in Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh reinforces that absent specified consequences, procedural non-compliance does not render the appeal incompetent.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is non-compliance with s.119A requiring deposit in a Government Treasury or RBI in favor of the Election Commission, but the Act prescribes no express penalty like dismissal for this default, unlike s.90(3) for petitions. The legislature deliberately distinguished such requirements, and the substantial deposit in court as security supports allowing the appeal to proceed. Despite strict election law observance, absence of mandatory dismissal favors setting aside the High Court's order.

cases.graph_reasoning: The impugned sections 12(1B) and 2(6A)(e) are deeming provisions to curb tax evasion by treating loans from closely-held companies as dividends, analogous to upheld provisions like s.23A and s.16(3). Precedents such as Navinchandra Mafatlal and Sardar Baldev Singh endorse a broad, liberal construction of Entry 82, List I, to include such fictions as income. Petitioner's challenges on legislative competence, Art.19(1)(f)(g), and Art.14 lack merit given the preventive rationale and constitutional support for reasonable restrictions.
cases.raw_reasoning: The impugned provisions under sections 2(6A)(e) and 12(1B) are anti-avoidance measures designed to treat loans or advances from closely-held companies to shareholders as deemed dividends to the extent of accumulated profits, preventing tax evasion through disguised distributions. These are narrowly tailored with clear conditions (e.g., excluding money-lending businesses, limited to accumulated profits), avoiding arbitrariness under Article 14, and retrospective application in s.12(1B) is permissible for revenue protection. Given judicial deference to Parliament's plenary taxing powers and the legitimacy of curbing avoidance, the constitutional challenge is unlikely to succeed, leading to dismissal of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellants failed to exhaust statutory remedies under Sections 30 and 32 of the Assam Sales Tax Act before seeking writ jurisdiction under Article 226, invoking the alternative remedy doctrine that restricts High Court discretion. The Explanation to Section 2(12) is intra vires the Government of India Act 1935 and deems sales taxable in Assam if goods are located there at contract time, as affirmed by the precedent in Tata Iron & Steel Co. v. State of Bihar. The Commissioner's finding on goods location, based on jute cultivation timelines, is factual and reasonable, undermined by appellants' non-production of books, making the appeal unlikely to succeed on certified Art.132 grounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Explanation to s.2(12) of the Assam Sales Tax Act is within the provincial legislature's competence under Entry 48, List II of the Government of India Act, 1935, as it reasonably deems sales taxable where goods are situated in the province at the time of contract, without encroaching on federal subjects like exports. The Commissioner's factual finding that jute was actually in Assam during the contract period is logical, based on the crop cultivation and marketing cycle, and not speculative, especially since appellants failed to produce complete books despite multiple opportunities under s.17. The High Court properly declined to re-appraise facts and upheld the assessments, warranting dismissal of the appeals.

cases.graph_reasoning: The provisions under s.27(3) and s.36 of the Mysore Town Municipalities Act are directory, not mandatory, and irregularities in notice service do not invalidate proceedings absent prejudice, which is absent here as 19/20 councillors attended and 15 voted in favor. The President received the requisition over 15 days prior, satisfying the proviso to s.23(9), and left voluntarily without contravening s.24(1)(a). Precedents confirm notices are given when sent and such provisions are directory, supporting upholding the no-confidence resolution and rejecting the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue of whether the three clear days' notice under s.27(3) is mandatory is likely viewed as directory given substantial compliance, actual service on most councillors on 10th October for a 14th meeting, posting at office, and 19/20 attendance including the appellant with no prejudice shown. The other contentions—presiding and 15-day notice under s.23(9) proviso—are meritless as the President left voluntarily and the proviso requires only signatures by one-third, not notice to all. High Court's reasoning aligns with standard interpretation distinguishing mandatory from directory provisions in municipal laws.

cases.graph_reasoning: The common law doctrine of Crown debt priority for tax dues over unsecured private debts, recognized by Indian High Courts pre-1950, constitutes 'law in force' under Article 372(1) of the Constitution and applies here. Cited precedents like Secretary of State v. Bombay Landing and Manickam Chettiar firmly support the Union's priority claim, unaffected by the republican Constitution or Income-tax Act s.46. Petitioner's challenges to jurisdiction and doctrine's continuance lack merit against this established framework.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Union of India's income-tax dues under Section 46(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, treated as arrears recoverable under the Public Demands Recovery Act, enjoy statutory priority over private decretal claims, including those secured by prior attachment before judgment. The Certificate Officer invoked Rule 22 of Schedule II to the Recovery Act to withhold payment, and recovery proceedings had commenced prior to the execution court's receipt of funds. The Calcutta High Court's ruling upholding this priority aligns with the legal position on Crown debts prevailing over unsecured or attached civil debts, warranting rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal concepts under Section 56 of the Contract Act clearly indicate that temporary requisition during wartime, especially without a fixed performance timeline, does not constitute frustration or discharge the contract due to supervening impossibility or unlawfulness. The appellant's reliance on unlawfulness is undermined by the doctrine that temporary impediments do not frustrate contracts contemplated amid war risks, as supported by the cited precedent Satyabrata Ghose itself. The suit for specific performance is not premature, as development was completed by the appeal stage, favoring rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: This case mirrors Satyabrata Ghose v. Mugneeram Bangur & Co. (1954 SCR 310), where the Supreme Court held that government requisition of land during WWII frustrated similar contracts for plot purchases under the Lake Colony Scheme, as it prevented road construction essential to the agreement. The contract here explicitly ties completion to road finishing, which requisition made impossible, invoking Section 56 of the Contract Act. The company's appeal on frustration grounds should succeed, setting aside the High Court's decree favoring specific performance.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Shri Jagannath Temple's unique status, national importance, and history of mismanagement justify special legislation under Article 14's reasonable classification test, as affirmed in precedents like Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan, which draw direct parallels to similar cases. The petitioner's claimed 'sole right of superintendence' does not constitute property under Articles 19(1)(f) or 31, as it merely involves replacing one office holder with another without acquisition or compensation issues. Historical evidence establishes the Temple as public, not private property of the Raja, undermining the core petitioner claims.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant conceded that the temple is public property belonging to the deity, not private property, weakening claims under Articles 19 and 31. Historical evidence shows state intervention in management due to mismanagement, justifying special legislation for this significant public temple without violating Article 14 or 26, as the state can regulate secular administration. The High Court's partial invalidation of one provision indicates balanced scrutiny, and Supreme Court precedent supports such regulatory measures for religious endowments.

cases.graph_reasoning: The seizure of cattle under Section 10 of the Cattle Trespass Act, even if illegal due to possession disputes, lacks the dishonest intention required for theft under IPC Section 378, as it follows the Act's scheme of moving cattle to the pound. Without theft, the prosecution party had no right of private defence of property, depriving them of justification for using force to rescue the cattle. The appellants, facing an armed rescue party, were entitled to private defence of person, justifying the injuries and leading to setting aside the convictions under IPC Sections 302 and 326 r/w 149.
cases.raw_reasoning: The seizure of cattle, even if illegal under the Cattle Trespass Act, does not amount to theft or robbery because the intention was to impound them lawfully rather than to dishonestly and permanently deprive the owners, lacking the mens rea for theft. Consequently, the prosecution party had no right of private defence of property to use force for rescue, and the High Court erred in equating the appellants to thieves or dacoits. The Sessions Judge's assessment of the appellants acting in private defence of their bodies, supported by the armed pursuit and mutual injuries, aligns better with IPC provisions on private defence.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's arguments strongly invoke the joint family nucleus presumption supported by precedents like Amritlal Sen and Appalaswami, emphasizing that properties in the names of family members are presumed joint if sufficient nucleus existed, which the High Court allegedly failed to clearly negate. Respondents' claims of personal earnings lack rebuttal strength against the presumption without fraud evidence, and the Karta's duty to account for current assets favors inquiry beyond his statements. Thus, the Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal to properly apply the presumption and direct assessment of nucleus for the disputed acquisitions.
cases.raw_reasoning: The plaintiff's claim that properties acquired post-1931 in the names of the Karta's son, wife, grandson, and especially brother-in-law were bought with joint family funds appears weak, as the family had a sufficient nucleus only for earlier admitted acquisitions, and family members like the son (who became Karnam) and brothers had independent earnings. Under Mitakshara law, the nucleus presumption does not extend automatically to such benami-like holdings without cogent proof, particularly for non-coparceners like the brother-in-law. The Supreme Court would likely accept the appeal at least partly, limiting joint properties to the admitted 10+25 acres and rejecting overbroad claims.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court explicitly found that alterations were not established, undermining the prosecution's theory of theft or cover-up as the purpose for detention. Section 53 requires 'wilful' detention, defined as deliberate and for some purpose, not mere negligence or inadvertence, and without proof of such purpose, the conviction lacks legal basis. Precedents emphasize mens rea or bad purpose for 'wilful' acts, supporting acquittal on the existing findings.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's key argument that 'wilful detention' under s.53 requires proof of an ulterior motive (like theft or alteration, both unproven) is weak, as the Supreme Court is examining 'wilful' in the Post Office Act's context, where it likely means intentional delay without justification, regardless of further criminal intent. Lower courts found detention deliberate based on evidence contradicting the 'too late' claim, and the Act's scheme punishes such postal misconduct strictly to ensure prompt service. The majority opinion's focus on statutory interpretation suggests upholding the conviction, rejecting the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court precedent in Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India directly holds that the Central Government exercises quasi-judicial jurisdiction under Rule 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, requiring adherence to natural justice principles, including disclosure of adverse materials like the State report. The Punjab High Court's dismissal of the writ petition erroneously classified this jurisdiction as administrative, mirroring the reversed view in the precedent. The appellants' partnership deed supports firm continuity despite partner changes, strengthening their case for reversal of the rejection orders.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellants invoked Rule 57 for review by the Central Government, which applies only when the State Government fails to dispose of the renewal application within a prescribed period, deeming it a refusal. Here, the Madhya Pradesh Government disposed of the application by rejecting it on substantive grounds (change in partnership constitution), albeit belatedly, so Rule 57 was inapplicable. The Central Government's rejection of the review and the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition indicate the appeal lacks merit, likely leading to rejection by the Supreme Court.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Tribunal's award of 50% back wages lacks specification of exact days or amounts, rendering it not arithmetically calculable as 'money due' under s.6-H(1), but requiring determination under s.6-H(2), consistent with cited precedents like MSS Transports and SS Shetty under analogous s.33C and s.20. Factual issues such as some workmen accepting alternative employment or not being parties further indicate money is not summarily 'due,' necessitating Labour Court adjudication. The Division Bench's interpretation erroneously treats it as under s.6-H(1), warranting the appeal's acceptance.
cases.raw_reasoning: The tribunal's award explicitly directed reinstatement and payment of 50% back wages for the period workmen were forcibly kept out of employment, making a determinate sum 'due under the award' within the scope of s.6-H(1) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, which permits issuance of a recovery certificate by the State Government upon satisfaction. Sub-section (2) applies only to benefits requiring computation of entitlement by a Labour Court, not to straightforward calculations of quantified dues under an award. The appellant's objections (e.g., some workmen re-employed or deceased) do not negate the applicability of s.6-H(1), as verification was partially done and further disputes could be resolved separately, favoring rejection of the appeal challenging the certificates.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal concepts establish Rule 27(2) as directory, not mandatory, permitting substantial compliance and STO satisfaction via other evidence under harmonious construction with Section 5(2)(a)(ii). Facts confirm the STO allowed deductions after being satisfied by the dealer's statement, with no proof that the buyer's registration certificate omitted the resale specification. Petitioner's insistence on exclusive proof via declaration fails against purposive interpretation and precedents favoring flexibility, likely leading to rejection of the challenge to deductions.
cases.raw_reasoning: The State's appeal challenges the High Court's ruling that the Sales Tax Officer was not wrong in allowing deductions under s.5(2)(a)(ii) despite no declaration produced under r.27(2), as evidenced by the check sheet. Sales tax laws typically require strict compliance with procedural rules like declaration forms to prevent evasion and claim deductions for sales to registered dealers. The Supreme Court is likely to interpret r.27(2) as mandatory, reversing the High Court and upholding the cross-objections.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioner's claim of indefeasible title via sanad is directly refuted by the precedent in Shri Mithoo Shahani v. Union of India, which holds that sanads do not immunize invalid allotments from cancellation on appeal or revision. Rule 2(h) is constitutionally valid under Article 14, as prospective laws creating distinctions between pre- and post-enactment allotments are not discriminatory. The allotment was invalid since the land was in an urban area per rule 2(h) at the time of allotment in December 1955.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's key argument that the sanad issued by the Managing Officer conferred an indefeasible title, immune from cancellation even on appeal or revision, was already rejected by the Supreme Court in the cited case of Shri Mithoo Shahani v. Union of India. The allotment violated Rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955, as the land was within municipal limits and in prior possession of non-displaced persons since before the allotment. Thus, the underlying allotment was illegal, justifying its cancellation, and the appeal lacks merit.

cases.graph_reasoning: The election petition failed to provide a concise statement of material facts under Section 83(1) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, and no prima facie case was established to justify inspection of ballot papers, which is restricted by ballot secrecy and not allowed for fishing expeditions. The Tribunal rightly refused inspection absent evidence on discrepancies or improper counting, and the High Court likely upheld this. Precedents like Bhim Sen v. Gopali do not broadly permit inspection without specifics, supporting rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Election Tribunal correctly required a prima facie case of specific irregularities in vote counting for inspection of ballot papers, to preserve ballot secrecy under the Representation of the People Act, 1951, and rules thereunder. Kidwai failed to substantiate such a case, with other pleas dismissed for lack of proof, making inspection unwarranted. The High Court erred in reversing without adequate reasons, as mere availability of papers does not justify routine inspection in election petitions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The facts establish a co-ownership concern with fixed shares (1/4 and 3/4), undivided lands, and a common manager appointed solely for cultivation convenience, without evidence of mutual agency or a partnership agreement under Section 4 of the Indian Partnership Act. Section 13 of the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act applies to common managers holding land for jointly interested persons like co-owners, and both parties concede it does not apply to partnerships. As a mixed question of fact and law, lower findings are vitiated if based on wrong legal principles, supporting acceptance of the appeal to apply Section 13.
cases.raw_reasoning: The assessee's claim that it is a 'company-ownership concern' rather than a partnership firm appears weak, as the facts indicate joint ownership of lands, cultivation through a common manager, and profit-sharing in fixed proportions, which align with the definition of a 'firm' under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, incorporated into the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act. The High Court correctly treated the nature of the assessee as a question of fact supported by circumstances, and there is no indication of perversity or legal error warranting interference by the Supreme Court. Thus, the appeal is likely to be rejected, upholding the assessment on the firm under s.3 instead of s.13 on the manager.

cases.graph_reasoning: The precedent in Bhau Ram v. Baijnath Singh directly holds that pre-emption on vicinage imposes unreasonable restrictions on Art.19(1)(f) rights, rendering it void, and this applies equally to customs as 'law' under Art.13(3)(a). Respondents' distinction between statute and custom fails since Art.13(1) voids customs with force of law inconsistent with fundamental rights. Petitioners' arguments align with constitutional text and precedent, favoring acceptance of the appeal to strike down the custom.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court in Bhau Ram v. Baijnath Singh had already held that pre-emption on the ground of vicinage imposes unreasonable restrictions on Article 19(1)(f) and is void, a precedent directly applicable here. The respondent's attempt to distinguish it as custom rather than statute is unlikely to succeed, as customary law is also subject to Article 13 and the same constitutional scrutiny. The High Court's reliance on Article 19(5) contradicts the Bhau Ram ruling, making it probable that the appeal will be accepted to declare the custom unconstitutional.

cases.graph_reasoning: The issue is identical to the recently decided Commissioner of Income-tax v. Swadeshi Cotton and Flour Mills, where the bonus for 1947 was held allowable as a deduction against profits of 1949, the previous year for AY 1950-51. The bonus liability crystallized in January 1949 via the Industrial Disputes Act award, making it deductible in the relevant previous year. As the Revenue's appeal involves the same point, it is likely to be rejected following the Swadeshi precedent.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appeal raises the identical legal point as in the lead case Commissioner of Income-tax v. Swadeshi Cotton and Flour Mills, on which the Supreme Court has just delivered judgment. The High Court decision under appeal followed the same reasoning as in the Swadeshi High Court case, against which the Commissioner successfully appealed or sought uniformity. Given the timing and linkage, the Supreme Court will likely apply its lead ruling to allow this appeal and set aside the High Court order for consistency.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Rajendra College is an 'admitted' college under Section 2(d) of the Bihar State Universities Act, limiting the University's powers under Section 30(d) to admission and withdrawal of privileges, not management or reconstitution of the Governing Body. Statutes 2(4) and part of 3(1) exceed these limits by empowering the Vice-Chancellor and Syndicate over admitted colleges, rendering them ultra vires and the impugned order invalid. Petitioner's statutory interpretation arguments outweigh respondent's public interest claims, favoring acceptance of the appeal and setting aside the order.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Bihar State Universities Act, 1960, particularly Section 4(10), empowers the University to manage and regulate affiliated colleges like Rajendra College, which was admitted under the Act. The Vice-Chancellor's authority to frame statutes for reconstituting the Governing Body aligns with the legislative intent to standardize governance of public institutions affiliated to the University. The appellant's claim of ultra vires lacks strong merit, as the High Court's validation of the statutes and order appears consistent with the statutory framework.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Subordinate Judge lacked jurisdiction to determine the quantum of compensation absent a reference by the Land Acquisition Officer under Section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act, as jurisdiction is statutory and must be strictly complied with; Section 30 references are limited to apportionment. Lack of inherent jurisdiction cannot be waived by the State's failure to raise the plea earlier, as supported by precedents like Nusserwanjee Pestonjee and Alderson v. Palliser. Arguments on comparable sale deeds are irrelevant without jurisdiction, warranting rejection of the appeal upholding the High Court's position.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court holds that the trial court lacked jurisdiction to determine the quantum of compensation because the Land Acquisition Officer made a reference only under Section 30 for apportionment, not under Section 18 for quantum, and such jurisdiction cannot be waived or arise otherwise. The High Court erred in negativing the State's plea and proceeding to reduce the compensation. Thus, the appellants' appeal to restore the trial court's higher award will be rejected, with the matter reverting to the Land Acquisition Officer's original award.

cases.graph_reasoning: The petitioners raise compelling procedural lapses, including the High Court's failure to independently review evidence under s.374 CrPC as mandated by Jumman v. State of Punjab, and non-examination of material witnesses under s.540 CrPC, which vitiates the trial in a death sentence context. Reliance on partisan faction witnesses with uniform testimony lacking specific overt acts undermines proof beyond reasonable doubt for vicarious liability under ss.149/301 IPC, per Baladin v. State of UP. In death appeals under Art.136, the Supreme Court would likely intervene to set aside or modify the convictions/sentences due to these evidentiary and procedural infirmities.
cases.raw_reasoning: The case involves convictions of 28 out of 35 accused under s.302/149 IPC in a factional rivalry with a large group, where establishing common object and individual participation for all members is often difficult due to potential over-implication. The High Court already acquitted 7, indicating evidentiary scrutiny, and Supreme Court appeals by special leave typically examine perversity in identification or witness reliability from the rival faction. Likely partial allowance, acquitting some or modifying sentences based on merits.

cases.graph_reasoning: The sale of machinery occurred effectively as part of winding up Free Press Company's business, as it transferred assets and ceased operations before formal liquidation, failing the condition under proviso to s.10(2)(vii) that requires sale while carrying on business; precedents like Liquidators of Pursa Ltd and KMS Reddy v West Coast Chemicals confirm such realizations during winding up are not business profits. Section 26(2) applies only to business profits under the 4th head of income, not capital gains under s.12B, as heads are mutually exclusive per United Commercial Bank Ltd. Thus, neither amount is assessable in the assessee's hands, favoring the respondent.
cases.raw_reasoning: The transaction involved transfer of the entire business undertaking, including rights, machinery, assets, book debts, and liabilities to the assessee-company, with net surplus credited to Free Press directors, rather than a distinct sale of machinery. This precludes application of the proviso to s.10(2)(vii), which requires a sale exceeding WDV, and s.12B capital gains, as no identifiable sale consideration for the machinery existed separately. s.26(2) applies to business profits prior to succession, not post-succession liquidation gains, supporting the High Court's ruling against Revenue; appeal likely rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court jurisprudence emphasizes that pleas like limitation, protective assessment, and procedural irregularities in tax matters must be raised before income-tax authorities and exhausted through alternative remedies, rather than invoking writ jurisdiction under Article 226 to bypass them. Petitioner's arguments on benami credits, witness examination, and notice validity are merits-based issues appropriately handled by the ITO, not suitable for writ relief. The challenge to the Saurashtra Ordinance's validity lacks strong support, making the appeal likely to be rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant sought to quash income tax notices via writ petition despite having an available statutory appeal against the assessment order to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, which courts typically require exhaustion before writ jurisdiction. The ITO's action under the escape assessment provisions was based on credible evidence of unexplained credits in the appellant's books, rejecting the benami claim as a factual matter unsuitable for writ interference. Such attempts to prolong tax proceedings through writs lack merit and are routinely dismissed by the Supreme Court.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court's finding that the poster Ex. 3 constitutes a corrupt practice under Section 123(4) RPA is supported by evidence of a specific false statement regarding Ramchander Chowdhary's misappropriation of cement for personal gain, relating to his personal conduct and reasonably calculated to prejudice his prospects. The appellant's arguments that it was a general allegation against the Congress Party or lacked voter knowledge fail, as precedents like T. K. Gangi Reddy affirm the burden shifts upon sufficient evidence and distinguish personal character involving moral corruption. No substantial merit in the non-joinder of Hariram, as no corrupt practice was alleged against him, making dismissal under Section 85 inapplicable.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant argues that the poster (Ex. 3) made general allegations against the Congress Party's misrule without clearly identifying Ramchander Chowdhary, lacking evidence that voters knew it referred to him or that it prejudiced his election prospects. The Court's analysis strictly dissects s.123(4) ingredients, requiring proof of falsity, lack of bona fide belief, relation to personal character, and design to prejudice voters, emphasizing freedom of speech unless malicious. These points indicate the High Court likely erred in finding corrupt practice without sufficient evidence, favoring acceptance of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appellant's benami claim is squarely barred by Section 66(1) CPC, which prohibits suits challenging court-certified purchases on benami grounds, and the exception in Section 66(2) does not extend to transferees from the alleged real owner asserting ownership title. The adverse possession plea was not raised in the suit, as per facts, and lacks the specific pleading required under doctrine and precedents like Bishun Dayal, rendering it unavailable. Lower court findings upholding the bar and pleading deficiency make rejection of the appeal highly likely.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's suit seeks to enforce a benami claim against properties bought at a court auction in the name of Hakir Alam, from whom the respondent claims title, but Section 66 CPC expressly bars suits challenging certified court sale purchasers or their transferees on benami grounds. Even assuming the benami nature is established, this statutory protection prevents the appellant, claiming through the alleged real purchaser, from succeeding. The High Court's dismissal aligns with this clear legal bar, warranting rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue is the construction of Rule 9 of Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827, which permits appointment of an administrator only if succession is disputed and none of the claimants is in possession at the commencement of proceedings. The petitioner's argument that the relevant date is the date of the order contradicts the plain text of Rule 9, which specifies 'commencement of proceedings,' and the lower court found no possession at that time, dismissing rent notes executed later due to lis pendens. Given the textual clarity and factual findings supporting the lower court's application, the Supreme Court is likely to uphold the appointment, rejecting the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Additional District Judge found a genuine dispute among multiple claimants to the estate of Kashibai, with no single party having taken exclusive possession, satisfying the conditions of Rule 9 of Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827 for appointing an administrator. The appellant's claim of possession over agricultural lands via rent notes was outweighed by the Revenue Tribunal's order entering respondents' names jointly as superior holders, indicating disputed possession. The High Court correctly upheld this, and the merits support rejecting the appeal challenging the appointment.

cases.graph_reasoning: The plain and literal meaning of Section 5(aa) of the WB Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 unambiguously vests forest lands 'together with' rights to trees held by 'any other person,' including severed third-party rights like the appellant's, without requiring common ownership. The 1957 amendment was purposively enacted to overcome High Court rulings excluding such rights, confirming retrospective broad vesting. The scheme's compensation provisions and Ninth Schedule immunity do not override this clear statutory language favoring the State.
cases.raw_reasoning: Section 5(aa), introduced with retrospective effect, explicitly vests in the State all lands in estates comprised in forests along with all rights to trees or produce held by intermediaries or any other persons, notwithstanding contrary judgments, directly overriding High Court rulings that excluded third-party cutting rights. This aligns with the purpose of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act as a land reform measure protected under Article 31A, making the appellant's pre-vesting contract rights subject to vesting. The constitutional validity challenge is unlikely to prevail given the era's deference to such retrospective amendments in estate acquisition laws, favoring rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal concepts establish an exception under Article 341 allowing courts to admit evidence to identify the caste intended in the Scheduled Castes Order when no such caste existed by that name in the state at the time, which applies here given the absence of 'Bhovi' in Mysore before 1956. Petitioner's strict textualist arguments on finality and spelling variants are undermined by this doctrine and historical evidence equating Voddar with Bhovi. Thus, the High Court's decision upholding respondent's SC status is likely affirmed, rejecting the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Supreme Court strongly affirms the finality of the Scheduled Castes notification under Article 341, agreeing with the appellant that ordinarily no evidence can be led to equate an unlisted caste (Voddar) with a listed one (Bhovi) absent explicit mention like brackets. However, it qualifies this by noting peculiar circumstances in the present case that prevent the appellant's strict argument from fully resolving the matter, implying the Court will permit evidence on the respondent's caste membership and likely affirm the High Court's reversal of the Tribunal, rejecting the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The geographical classification continuing the Bhopal Act in the former territory post-reorganisation is valid under Article 14, as it is based on historical reasons with a rational nexus, supported by Section 119 of the States Reorganisation Act and precedents like Bhaiyalal Shukla and Gwalior Sugar Co. The passage of time does not render it discriminatory if initially justified, and the petition lacks adequate particulars and evidence of arbitrariness or overall tax burden disparity. The presumption of constitutionality for taxing statutes further favors upholding the law, leading to rejection of the taxpayer's appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court declared the Bhopal Act unconstitutional under Article 14 for applying only to the former Bhopal territory post-reorganisation, creating differential tax treatment. However, the Supreme Court excerpt emphasizes that geographical classifications based on historical reasons are permissible under Article 14 if rationally related to the statute's object, citing precedents like Bhaiyalal Shukla, Gwalior Sugar Co., and others that upheld similar continuations of pre-reorganisation laws. This indicates the Court will likely reverse the High Court, accepting the State's appeal that the Act is valid.

cases.graph_reasoning: The tenants' suit is not maintainable as it is barred under Schedule GG Cl.2 of the BMC Act, which provides an appeal remedy to the City Civil Court for aggrieved persons including tenants, a remedy they failed to exhaust. Provisions of ss.354R and 354RA impose reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5) in public interest for dilapidated buildings, satisfying natural justice via notice, objections, and appeal rights. Claims of ultra vires, mala fides, and fraud lack merit given the buildings' condition evidenced by 138 repair notices and the demolition agreement.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court's remand for additional evidence on mala fides lacks foundation, as the plaint initially had no specific particulars of mala fides, and inferences from documents alone do not justify directing examination of officials at the Letters Patent appeal stage. The suit challenging the statutory clearance order under Sections 354R and 354RA of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act appears barred by Clause 2 of Schedule GG, prioritizing municipal remedies over civil suits. The constitutional challenge under Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) is weak, given the public interest in clearing dilapidated buildings, making the appeal likely to succeed in setting aside the remand and dismissing the suit.

cases.graph_reasoning: The cited precedent in Liquidators of Pursa Limited v. CIT directly holds that surplus on sale of assets by liquidator after business cessation is not taxable under the second proviso to S.10(2)(vii). Harmonious construction requires the proviso to align with S.10(1), mandating business carried on during the previous year, which was not the case post-December 1954 closure before the March 1955 sale. Strict construction of taxing statutes and limited scope of statutory fictions favor the assessee, rejecting the revenue's broad interpretation of the amendment.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Tribunal's estimation of the buildings' value was based on unsubstantiated surmises, justifying the High Court's interference, but this does not resolve the core issue. The second proviso to S.10(2)(vii), post-1949 amendment, deems recoupment of depreciation as taxable profits irrespective of whether the assets were used in the business during the previous year, overturning the High Court's holding on non-applicability. Thus, the Supreme Court is likely to accept the Revenue's appeal, set aside the High Court's decision on taxability, and possibly restore or modify the quantum based on accepted valuations.

cases.graph_reasoning: The return filed on September 4, 1948, in response to the s.34 notice constitutes a valid return under s.22(3), as it need not be suo motu or voluntary. Precedent in Commissioner of Income Tax v Ranchhodas Karsondas prevents the Department from ignoring such a return and issuing a fresh notice under s.34(1)(a), rendering the 1953 reassessment invalid. The second proviso to s.34(3) does not apply, as lower courts' reliance on it fails given the valid return allowing assessment under s.23 until 1949.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court held the 1953 reassessment notice invalid, ruling that the 1948 return, even pursuant to an allegedly invalid notice, constitutes a valid return under s.22(3) that cannot be ignored to trigger fresh s.34 proceedings, following CIT v. Ranchhodas Karsondas. The appellant's key argument that the return must be strictly voluntary and suo motu is refuted in the excerpt's analysis, which clarifies s.22(3) allows returns before assessment without requiring suo motu filing. This alignment with precedent and rejection of the revenue's distinction strongly favors upholding the High Court, rejecting the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal concepts and cited precedents, including Moti Ram Deka, explicitly state that termination by reduction in superannuation age does not constitute 'removal' under Article 311, distinguishing it from other terminations. The rule under Article 309 is prospective with a proviso to avoid dislocation, not retrospective, and applies uniformly without violating Article 14, as upheld by the Allahabad High Court in Ram Autar Pandey. Petitioner's arguments misapply precedents and lack merit against established doctrine.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's claim under Article 311 fails as reducing the retirement age constitutes superannuation, not 'removal' from service, distinguished from Moti Ram Deka which did not address retirement rules. The government's power under Article 309 allows such changes, including retrospective deeming provisions to manage service continuity without violating equality under Article 14, as the schedule provides reasonable classification to prevent dislocation. The arguments lack merit, favoring rejection of the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The transfers under Section 127(1) were within the same city and locality in Calcutta, invoking the proviso that dispenses with both the opportunity to be heard and the requirement to record reasons, as no prejudice arises in such administrative intra-locality shifts. Petitioners' argument that recording reasons remains mandatory despite the proviso is contradicted by the statutory interpretation linking both requirements and precedents like Pannalal Binjraj upholding similar transfer powers. The court is likely to dismiss the writ petitions, upholding the orders' validity.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether recording reasons under s.127(1) is mandatory for intra-locality transfers covered by the proviso, which explicitly dispenses with the opportunity to be heard. The Court's analysis links the recording of reasons to the opportunity requirement, which is absent under the proviso, rendering reasons unnecessary for such minor transfers. Thus, the transfer orders are valid, and the appeal against the High Court's dismissal will likely be rejected.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 11(2) exceeds the State legislature's competence under Entry 54, List II, as recovering non-exigible amounts wrongly collected as tax is neither incidental to taxing sales/purchases nor a penalty, but amounts to confiscation. Respondent's arguments invoking penalty or Entry 26 (trade/commerce) fail, as the provision enables fiscal recovery as land revenue arrears without regulating trade. Precedents like Indian Aluminium support invalidating similar provisions, favoring quashing the assessment order and accepting the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: Section 11(2) is a valid ancillary provision to the sales tax legislation under Entry 54 of List II, as it ensures amounts collected as tax, even if unauthorized, are remitted to the government to prevent unjust enrichment and facilitate proper tax administration. Such provisions are standard in sales tax laws and within state legislative competence, with the High Court's alternative reliance on Entry 26 List II (offences against List II matters) providing additional support. The appellant's argument that unauthorized collections fall outside taxing power is unlikely to prevail, as courts uphold measures incidental to levy and collection.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Bihar Waqfs Act, particularly Sections 27, 32, and 37, clearly empowers the Majlis and Sadr to inquire into accounts, remove a Mutwalli for proven mismanagement (including pre-Act conduct, as retrospectivity applies without vested rights), and appoint a temporary Mutwalli without needing District Judge ratification. Sections 27 and 32 are intra vires the Constitution, aligning with the Supreme Court's prior validation of Section 58 in Bashiruddin Ashraf v. State of Bihar. The petitioner's jurisdictional and constitutional challenges lack merit given the statutory framework and factual findings of misconduct.
cases.raw_reasoning: The appellant's primary contentions regarding the lack of jurisdiction for pre-amendment enquiries and non-retrospectivity of s.27(2)(h)(iii) of the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1951, are weak, as waqf supervisory powers under the 1947 Act applied to registered waqfs from 1948, and administrative proceedings for ongoing mismanagement are typically not invalidated for pending matters. Constitutional challenges under Articles 19, 25, 26, and 31 fail, as State regulation of waqf properties for proper management is permissible and does not infringe fundamental rights. Factual findings of mismanagement, misappropriation, and disobedience upheld by lower courts indicate no perversity, making the appeal unlikely to succeed.

cases.graph_reasoning: The explanation to Section 24 of the Indian Stamp Act applies only when property is sold 'subject to' a mortgage, meaning the purchaser assumes the encumbrance; here, vendees paid off Rs. 4,89,000 to secure clear title, with vendors liable for Rs. 11,000, so it does not qualify. Consideration for stamp duty under Article 23 is based on the amount set forth in the deed for immovable property (Rs. 1,00,000), and payments to the bank prior to execution are not deemed part thereof. Strict construction of taxing statutes favors the taxpayer, rejecting inclusion of mortgage amounts to prevent avoidance claims by petitioner.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court held the stamp duty payable only on Rs. 1,00,000, but Section 24 of the Stamp Act and its Explanation deem unpaid mortgage money secured on the conveyed property as part of the consideration for ad valorem duty, as illustrated in the section where duty is levied on stated price plus mortgage debt. Here, the deed explicitly states the properties are subject to the bank's charge (part of Rs. 10 lakhs mortgage), to be paid off by payments totaling Rs. 5 lakhs, fitting the 'subject to mortgage' scenario and preventing undervaluation. The Supreme Court is likely to overturn the High Court, holding higher consideration (likely Rs. 5,55,000 or attributable mortgage share) for duty calculation.

cases.graph_reasoning: The statutory scheme of Section 25A requires an order under sub-section (1) as a precondition for sub-section (2), which mandates assessment as if no partition followed by apportionment, with the proviso imposing personal joint and several liability only thereafter; here, no Section 25A(2) order was made, assessments were finalized prior to the 1952 Section 25A(1) order, and reopening final assessments is impermissible. Recovery from personal remuneration under Section 46(5) is invalid absent established personal liability of the members. Petitioner's argument that the proviso operates independently without a Section 25A(1) order contradicts the plain text and structure of the provision, favoring rejection of the appeal on procedural and statutory interpretation grounds.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court rightly held that after the order under Section 25A(1) recognizing the partition, an apportionment of tax liability under Section 25A(2) is required before any recovery proceedings can be initiated against individual members, as per the statutory scheme and the proviso to Section 25A(2). The assessments were made on the HUF, and without apportionment, the former members cannot be treated as defaulters personally liable for the HUF's tax under Section 46(5). The Income-tax Act, 1922, mandates strict compliance with Section 25A to enforce liability on members of a disrupted Hindu undivided family, filling the earlier lacuna explicitly through this procedure.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court is likely to reject the appeal, as precedents like Marachalil Pakku v. State of Madras, Bombadhar Pradhan v. State of Orissa, and Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab establish that acquittal of a principal offender in a separate trial does not bar constructive liability of other accused under IPC Sections 34 or 149. Petitioner's res judicata arguments from Pritam Singh and Sambasivam apply to subsequent proceedings involving the same parties, not independent trials of different accused like here. The High Court's reliance on eyewitness testimony establishing the appellant's presence and common intention provides sufficient independent basis for conviction under S.302/34.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court properly invoked Section 34 IPC, finding direct testimony that the appellant stood armed beside Ramhans during the murder and attempt to murder, establishing common intention independent of Section 149. The separate acquittal of Ramhans does not bar the appellant's conviction, as trials are independent and evidence supports his active participation. Given consistent findings by Sessions Judge and High Court on prosecution witnesses, the Supreme Court is likely to uphold the conviction and dismiss the appeal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The assessment list suffers from critical procedural defects, including invalid delegation of objection-hearing powers to a Sub-Committee under S.78 MP Municipalities Act (limited to President/VP/officers), publication based on a revoked slab system resolution violating S.136 and Art.265's strict compliance requirement, and improper use of S.141 for substantive amendments post-suspension instead of de novo preparation under Ss.134-140. Objections lodged were not on a lawfully prepared list with correct rates, denying natural justice under audi alteram partem. Petitioners' claims of finality under S.140 and amendability under S.141 fail as they cannot cure foundational illegality, making the High Court's intervention under Art.226 warranted despite alternative remedies.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Collector's suspension order explicitly required the assessment to be 'properly revised afresh,' implying a complete restart of the statutory process under sections 134-140 of the MP Municipalities Act, including preparation of a new draft list by the Chief Municipal Officer, publication under s.136, and hearing objections from all assessees. Instead, the Council selectively issued notices to only 300 persons under s.141 (revision power post-finalization), heard their objections, and confirmed the list without full republication or addressing the widespread procedural defects and partiality in the prior Sub-Committee process involving 2200 objections. This selective approach bypasses the Act's mandatory scheme for assessment lists, rendering the February 24, 1964 confirmation invalid, so the Supreme Court would likely uphold the High Court's quashing.

cases.graph_reasoning: The partnership deed treats 'Yarn Shop', a firm, as a partner with a collective share of 0-6-9, but under Section 4 of the Partnership Act, a firm is not a legal entity and cannot enter into partnerships; only individuals can be partners. The cited precedent Dulichand Laxminarayan v. CIT explicitly holds that partnerships involving firms cannot be registered under Section 26-A, requiring specification of individual shares. Despite arguments on substance over form and sufficient description via scheme, strict compliance with Section 26-A mandates individual shares, favoring rejection of registration.
cases.raw_reasoning: The partnership application lists another firm ('Ms Kylasa Sarabhiah a firm') as a partner with specified sub-partners and shares, which violates the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, as a firm cannot be a partner in another firm since firms lack separate legal personality. Section 26-A requires the firm to be lawfully constituted under a genuine instrument specifying individual shares of partners, a condition not met here. Strict compliance is mandated for registration benefits, justifying denial by ITO, Tribunal, and High Court, with the appeal likely rejected on merits.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Madras City Tenants Protection Act prioritizes tenant protection for improvements, with S.4(4) mandatorily dismissing the suit if compensation is not paid within three months, paramount over any formal defects in the S.4(1) decree under harmonious construction. Petitioner correctly argues that the High Court's misconstruction cannot circumvent this mandatory provision, as supported by the doctrine emphasizing S.4(4)'s application even to decrees lacking explicit timelines. Respondent's call for decree amendment undermines the Act's protective intent, favoring acceptance of the appeal to enforce dismissal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The High Court correctly interpreted that S.4(4) applies only to a decree compliant with S.4(1), which mandates a specific direction for payment within three months; the original decree lacked this explicit direction, so the three-month period did not trigger automatic dismissal. The tenant's argument that any defect cannot circumvent the mandatory provision fails, as S.4(4) presupposes a properly framed decree under S.4(1). The landlord's deposit shortly after the dispute arose further supports rejection of the appeal, allowing execution.

cases.graph_reasoning: Article 145(1)(a) provides an independent rule-making power to the Supreme Court to prescribe qualifications for persons practising before it, including for Advocates-on-Record under Rules 16 and 17. Section 58(3) of the Advocates Act 1961 explicitly subjects the right to practise to Supreme Court rules, preventing it from overriding such rules. The petitioner's arguments conflate parliamentary legislative power under Entry 77 with the Court's regulatory authority, which precedents like Aswini Kumar Ghosh distinguish by upholding the plead-act separation.
cases.raw_reasoning: The petitioner's claim under Section 58(3) of the Advocates Act for an absolute right to act as well as plead is explicitly made subject to Supreme Court rules, and Section 52 saves the Court's rule-making power under Article 145(1)(a) to regulate persons practicing before it, including qualifications for Advocates on Record. The excerpt distinguishes prior precedents like Aswini Kumar Ghosh, noting they apply only absent rules, and affirms the validity of Rule 16's requirements for training, office, and clerk. Thus, the rules are intra vires, warranting dismissal of the petition challenging their validity.

cases.graph_reasoning: The legal concepts, including the doctrine of wrong recital allowing validity under alternative powers like Section 5 of Madhya Bharat Act 1 of 1948, and necessary intendment removing vested appeal rights on facts, directly refute the petitioner's challenges to the 1949 amendments. The Madhya Bharat Taxes on Income Validation Act 38 of 1954 explicitly validates the 1940-1948 assessments under old Tax Rules despite the Finance Act 1950, and is not discriminatory under Art. 14 as it targets past irregular proceedings on a distinct footing. Supreme Court precedent favors upholding such curative validations for tax assessments, leading to rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The 1949 amendments to the Tax Rules were made under the continued rule-making power post-merger, compliant with the first exercise exception under Rule 17 requiring no previous publication. The Finance Act 1950's requirement for Income Tax authorities was a procedural irregularity cured by Parliament's Validation Act, a standard legislative measure typically upheld by the Supreme Court. The merits favor validity of the provisions and assessments, leading to rejection of the appeal challenging them.

cases.graph_reasoning: The hathchitha entry, made by another at the illiterate chowkidar's request, does not qualify under Section 35 of the Evidence Act due to low probative value, failing to conclusively prove the appellant's age while the burden lies on the respondent to establish disqualification under Article 137, which remains unproven. Allegations of corrupt practice under Section 123(4) RP Act are disputed and do not clearly amount to attacks on personal character, with the petitioner challenging the High Court's interpretation of Exhibit 10. Insufficient evidence supports subsisting contracts under Section 7(d), tilting merits in favor of upholding the election, leading to acceptance of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The Election Tribunal found none of the three grounds—underage, government contract, or corrupt practice via leaflets—established after considering evidence, dismissing the election petition. The High Court agreed the contract allegation was not proved but set aside the election on the remaining grounds, yet refused to declare the respondent elected, indicating insufficient proof for the respondent's claim. The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal, finding the High Court's reversal erroneous in evidence appreciation, as the petitioner bears the strict burden to prove disqualification or corrupt practice, restoring the tribunal's order.

cases.graph_reasoning: The High Court erred in treating Ram Surat Choudhury's confession as substantive evidence against the appellants, violating Section 30 of the Evidence Act and precedents like Bhuboni Sahu v King and Emperor v Lalit Mohan Chuckerbutty, which limit it to corroborating other evidence only. The other evidence—bloodstained shirt and traces on Haricharan Kurmi's nails, plus general stains—is circumstantial and insufficient to prove participation in the dacoity with murder under IPC Section 396, lacking direct identification or strong corroboration. The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal and set aside the conviction due to this legal error and evidentiary weakness.
cases.raw_reasoning: The core issue is whether the Patna High Court erred in treating the confession of co-accused Ram Surat Choudhury as substantive evidence against the appellants under Section 30 of the Indian Evidence Act, contrary to the judicial consensus that such confessions are only corroborative. The matter was referred to a Constitution Bench to examine conflicting observations from the Supreme Court's prior decision in Ram Prakash v. State of Punjab, indicating potential legal error in the High Court's approach. Given the narrow question of law raised and the Supreme Court's scrutiny, the appeal is likely to be accepted, at least partly, by clarifying the law and possibly setting aside the convictions or enhanced death sentences for the appellants.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Tribunal's finding that the fixed deposit did not represent the assessee's concealed income is a question of fact supported by lack of direct evidence linking it to secreted profits, with mere suspicion insufficient under established principles like 'suspicion cannot take place of evidence.' Courts defer to Tribunal findings unless perverse under Wednesbury unreasonableness, which is not met here as reasonable inferences from basic facts are factual. The petitioner's argument that facts compel only one inference fails, as mixed questions require perversity for reviewability under Section 66(1), leading to rejection of the appeal.
cases.raw_reasoning: The three fixed deposits followed an identical pattern of unexplained cash tendered at the same bank branch and remitted to Jamnagar in the names of partners' sons, strongly suggesting secreted profits of the assessee firm. The Tribunal upheld addition for two deposits due to direct links to the firm's overdraft but excluded the third solely for its use in Hanuman Sugar Mills overdraft, despite partners' controlling interest via managing agency and absence of any alternative explanation. This distinction lacks substantial basis, rendering the Tribunal's inference perverse and amenable to correction as an error of law apparent on record.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Central Government's rejection under S.9(2) without affording the appellant an opportunity to rebut the presumption of voluntary acquisition via Pakistan passport under Schedule III Clause 3 violates natural justice principles (audi alteram partem) in the quasi-judicial inquiry mandated by Rule 30. Precedents like Izhar Ahmad Khan upheld the validity of S.9 and the rules but did not address procedural infirmities in specific orders. The court is likely to accept the appeal, set aside the order, and remand for a proper hearing.
cases.raw_reasoning: Parliament possesses plenary powers under Article 11 to regulate citizenship, rendering Section 9 of the Citizenship Act, 1955, intra vires and imposing an objective test for termination upon voluntary acquisition of foreign citizenship via a passport. The High Court correctly held that no quasi-judicial inquiry into voluntariness is mandated, as the legal consequences follow automatically from the established fact of obtaining a Pakistan passport. The Central Government's rejection under Section 9(2) without a hearing aligns with the statutory framework, upholding the deportation order.

cases.graph_reasoning: The suit is governed by Article 144 of the Limitation Act, not Article 142, as the plaintiffs (heirs) were never in possession and thus not dispossessed. Tacking of adverse possession is not permitted between independent trespassers like Bakshi Singh (under invalid adoption) and the Raja (superior landlord), lacking privity or jural relationship under Section 2, as emphasized by doctrines and precedents like Agency Co v Short. Consequently, limitation did not commence or complete prior to the heirs' suit post-1930, rendering it within time and the petitioners' appeal (claiming bar) likely rejected.
cases.raw_reasoning: The suit falls under Article 144 of the Limitation Act, 1908, as Articles 141 and 142 do not apply per the parties' concessions and the analysis that plaintiffs were never in possession as heirs. Adverse possession by Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh ran from 1930 but was interrupted in 1938 when the Raja obtained possession via decree before completing 12 years, starting a fresh period of adverse possession from October 1938; no privity exists between prior possessors and the Raja to allow tacking.
